Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A child's bad behavior won't last; they will mature with time.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common Akan proverb emphasizing patience in child upbringing.
First Example Sentence: Abɔfra boɔ nkyɛ, ɔbɛyɛ ɔkɛse a ɔbɛte n'adwene.
Second Example Sentence: Mma yɛmfa abɔfra no bo nntɔ no; abɔfra boɔ nkyɛ.
Third Example Sentence: W'ahu no dodo? Gyae na kae sɛ abɔfra boɔ nkyɛ.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: One cannot expect the impossible; different beings produce their own kind.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Like produces like; the impossible does not happen.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Draws on Akan symbolism of natural order.
First Example Sentence: Kɔtɔ nwo anomaa, enti wo mmarima mmɔfra no yɛ wo ho.
Second Example Sentence: Nnipa a wonim wɔn ho, wonim sɛ kɔtɔ nwo anomaa.
Third Example Sentence: Yɛbɛtumi aka sɛ kɔtɔ nwo anomaa wɔ asɛm yi mu.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Success is determined early; preparation starts from the beginning.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Widely quoted among Akan elders during advice.
First Example Sentence: Agoro beso a, efiri anopa nti, yɛsrɛ no ntete no yie.
Second Example Sentence: Wopɛ sɛ wudwane yie a, kae sɛ agoro beso a, efiri anopa.
Third Example Sentence: Mpanimfoɔ ka sɛ agoro beso a, efiri anopa.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A dangerous situation will eventually reveal itself.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Linked to Akan storytelling using snakes as metaphors.
First Example Sentence: Nanka bɛkyɛre ne ho na yɛahu nea ɛwɔ mu.
Second Example Sentence: Sɛ wowɔ abotare a, nanka bɛkyɛre ne ho.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Disgrace is unbecoming of a person.
First Example Sentence: Animguase mfata ɔnipa, enti yɛnnya nidi.
Second Example Sentence: Ɔbarima bɛyɛ den a, animguase mfata no.
Third Example Sentence: Ka kyerɛ no sɛ animguase mfata ɔnipa.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: When trouble arises, everyone is affected.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: A rising tide lifts all boats—negatively.
First Example Sentence: Nsuo beto a, ɛka nkɔtɔ, enti yɛn hwɛ yɛn ho.
Second Example Sentence: Yɛka sɛ nsuo beto a, ɛka nkɔtɔ wɔ amanyɔsɛm mu.
Third Example Sentence: Nsuo beto a, ɛka nkɔtɔ; yɛnyɛ yɛn ho den.

Idiom (Twi): Sɛ wo werɛ fi a, yɛkae
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: If you forget, we will remind you.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: We'll remind you if you forget.
First Example Sentence: Sɛ wo werɛ fi a, yɛkae na yɛmma wo werɛ.
Second Example Sentence: Yɛka sɛ sɛ wo werɛ fi a, yɛkae wɔ abusua mu.
Third Example Sentence: Sɛ wo werɛ fi a, yɛkae paa.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A caring person never abandons their dependents.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: A protector never forsakes their own.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Akan proverbs about parenthood and responsibility.
First Example Sentence: Akokɔbaatan nni ne mma akyi; ɔbɔ wɔn ho ban.
Second Example Sentence: Nana no ka sɛ akokɔbaatan nni ne mma akyi.
Third Example Sentence: Ɛyɛ nokware sɛ akokɔbaatan nni ne mma akyi.

Idiom (Twi): Wopɛ akɔtɔ a, sua nsuo kɔtɔ
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Prepare adequately for what you seek.
First Example Sentence: Wopɛ akɔtɔ a, sua nsuo kɔtɔ, na ɛyɛ wo yie.
Second Example Sentence: Nnipa a wɔpɛ nkɔso sua nsuo kɔtɔ.
Third Example Sentence: Yɛsrɛ no: wopɛ akɔtɔ a, sua nsuo kɔtɔ.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: What is ancient is regarded as ancestral; old things have historical significance.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Old things are respected for their history.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Relates to Akan reverence for ancestors and traditions.
First Example Sentence: Se tete wɔfrɛ no nsamanfo, enti yɛdi abosom som.
Second Example Sentence: Aberewa no bɔɔ me kɔkɔ sɛ se tete wɔfrɛ no nsamanfo.
Third Example Sentence: Wopɛ sɛ wusu nyansa a, kae sɛ se tete wɔfrɛ no nsamanfo.
